entry.title: Chrome not respecting imported certificate when expired
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. go to chrome://settings/certificates and import an expired cert 2. try to visit the site, you'll encounter not safe warning
# Problem Description I want Chrome to accept an expired certificate (signed by letsencrypt) for a specific site. I've downloaded the pem file, renamed it to crt, and imported it in Chrome. I can see the fingerprints and everything looks fine.
Only issue is interacting with the site still throws warnings such as certificate invalid. Other cases such as ERR_PROXY_CERTIFICATE_INVALID can't even be temporarily disable by for example by clicking Advanced->Proceed to ... (unsafe).
--ignore-certificate-errors works, but it's unsafe for ALL certificates, which is not what I want.
# Summary Chrome not respecting imported certificate when expired
# Additional Data Category: Network / Downloading \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: No

entry.title: Apps that use Android System Webview don't load their content
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Just load app that uses ASW e.g. Gmail - open specific e-mail and check if it will be loaded properly
# Problem Description Apps that use Android System Webview don't load their content - they are getting stucked on loadin e.g. Gmail when user tries to read specific e-mail message.
Of course I tried to clear memory (ASW and not working apps), checked Internet connection, security settings etc.
Many people also reported this problem when I put the opinion in Google Play store about ASW
Environment: Android 13, OneUI, Samsung S20 Ultra
# Additional Comments In my opinion urgent matter, because it blocks many everyday apps on Android
# Summary Apps that use Android System Webview don't load their content
# Additional Data Category: Network / Downloading \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: Yes

entry.title: Can't open any website.
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Open Chrome. 2. Type any website address. 3. Get an error says "ERR_CONNECTION_RESET".
# Problem Description .69 version is fine. But after upgraded to .70, all tabs are cleared, and display a sad face with ERR_CONNECTION_RESET. Tried re-install and the result is the same. There must be something wrong with this version. Most funny thing is, it even can't open local address like router page 192.168.1.1.
# Summary Can't open any website.
# Additional Data Category: Network / Downloading \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: N/A

entry.title: [Chromium GSoC] Request for Feedback (chromestatus)
entry.content:
*Instructions:*
*1) Choose if this is a general question about the project (if so choose template 1) or if this is a request for a review of a proposal (if so choose template 2 below)*
*2) Fill in the template completely and delete the instructions and the unused template*
*3) Update the title to reflect your question or "proposal submission for <your name>"*
*4) Submit and wait for the mentors to provide feedback*.
*--------------- Template 1 ------------------*
**Question about Project**
*Delete this and the below paragraphs and ask your question here, recall that there is lots of material for routine questions. Please go through the [project list](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/15tLikPVkKrkz53RVG1ncY-8PpWA4dgZU0-5kl-uB4dg/), if you are interested get started on the starter bugs / starter milestone listed on the project doc of each project.*
*If you want a head start or interested in contributing to chromium you can check out the “[Life of a Chromium Developer](https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/g/chromium-dev/c/ybLzH8-FoTc/m/YhTe2g9L7CUJ)”, “[contributing](https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/master/docs/contributing.md)”, or “[getting involved](https://www.chromium.org/getting-involved)” for information about getting the code and general flow of making a change to the code base.*
*If you have general questions not about a project you should instead email the mailing list chromium-gsoc@chromium.org (or file a bug with the [default template](https://g-issues.chromium.org/issues/new?component=1515734&template=1947555)) and the admins can assist you.*
*--------------- Template 2 ------------------*
**Request For Project Proposal Review**
Please use our [template for a proposal](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1IOj4hSdPl8h1-8zYK_Gt3OxA0R44SLbmr-ZH3f9yDXM/edit?usp=sharing)
But we also encourage you to read GSoC's [writing a proposal](https://google.github.io/gsocguides/student/writing-a-proposal) and [example proposal](https://google.github.io/gsocguides/student/proposal-example-1). We suggest you reach out early engage with the starter bug of your project, and submit a proposal soon after you have a handle on the problem.
* Link to Google doc that contains your proposal: * Desired Project length (if different from project slide's suggestions): * Desired Project size (if different from project slide's suggestions): *Small/Medium/Large* * Any additional comments:

entry.title: WebRTC roll blocked due to missing default implementation of RtcPeerConnectionInterface::ShouldFireNegotiationNeededEvent
entry.content:
In webrtc https://webrtc-review.googlesource.com/c/src/+/340481, mock for webrtc::PeerConnectionInterface::ShouldFireNegotiationNeededEvent is added.
Unfortunately it breaks test RTCPeerConnectionHandlerTest.OnRenegotiationNeeded.
I suggest disabling this test, importing the latest webrtc and then fix the test.
See https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5322682?tab=checks

entry.title: Let's make native vertical tabs similar to edge or safari?
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. open chrome 2. cry
# Problem Description Let's make native vertical tabs similar to edge or safari?
current extensions with vertical tabs are terrible, they take up a lot of screen space, are not optimized, in the dark theme they have a white scroll(!) lol, and when you turn them on - horizontal tabs are not removed
# Summary Let's make native vertical tabs similar to edge or safari?
# Additional Data Category: UI \ Chrome Channel: Not sure \ Regression: N/A

entry.title:
Tests are failing: tts_extension_apitest.cc(625): Value of: RunExtensionTest("tts_engine/update_voices_api")
 Actual: false
Expected: true
Failed 2 of 3 tests
entry.content:
This bug is for all test failures where the primary error message is similiar to the following (ignoring numbers and hexadecimal values): tts_extension_apitest.cc(625): Value of: RunExtensionTest(\"tts_engine/update_voices_api\")\n Actual: false\nExpected: true\nFailed 2 of 3 tests
The following test(s) were observed to have matching failures at this time (at most five examples listed): - ninja://chrome/test:browser_tests/TtsApiTest.UpdateVoicesApi/ServiceWorker.0
These test failures are causing problem(s) which require your attention, including: - many gardened builders are failing
See current problems, failure examples and more in LUCI Analysis at: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/p/chromium/rules/0848341b103cf76930f0c9a6396e25d5
How to action this bug: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#new-bug-filed Provide feedback: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#feedback Was this bug filed in the wrong component? See: https://luci-analysis.appspot.com/help#component-selection

entry.title: Missing pen tablet input on ozone-wayland backend
entry.content:
# Steps to reproduce the problem 1. Run chrome with ozone-wayland backend on a wayland compositor 2. use pen tablet on chrome window 3. pen input missing
# Problem Description It would seem that chrome's ozone-wayland backend does not handle pen tablet input, so apps that has drawing capabilities can't be used to it's fullest
# Additional Comments The following attachements are the WAYLAND_DEBUG logs for ozone-wayland when a pen tablet hovers over it
# Summary Missing pen tablet input on ozone-wayland backend
# Custom Questions #### Please select a label to classify your issue: Type-Bug - Software not working correctly
# Additional Data Category: Other \ Chrome Channel: Stable \ Regression: No

entry.title: Remove initiating_element from form_util::ApplyFormAction()
entry.content:
`form_util::ApplyFormAction()` has special treatment for the `initiating_element` parameter. I think we can keep this special treatment but remove that parameter.
Why would removing the `initiating_element` parameter be good? - `AutofillAgent::last_queried_element_` is passed for that parameter. `last_queried_element_` has a troubled semantics itself. Eliminating references to `last_queried_element_` is a step towards fixing its semantics or eliminating it. - As a step towards fixing issue 40275791, Jihad has [a CL](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/5268782/17) that passes the triggered element all the way from the browser to `ApplyFormAction()`. We wouldn't need that if we can eliminate the parameter. We could also simplify his [followup CL](https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/4700769/15) and pass a vector of `FormFieldData::FillData` instead of of a vector of `FormData::FillData` in the mojo message `ApplyFormAction()`. - The `ApplyFormFunction()` is too complex. Simplifying it would be great.
What is [`initiating_element` parameter](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2213;drc=8b80267364695624baf28f6b4ae7dfe0c1aed9c1) currently used for? 1. It is used to [extract](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2219-2225;drc=8b80267364695624baf28f6b4ae7dfe0c1aed9c1) the `WebFormControlElement`s of a form. This vector is used for three purposes: 1. It is used in [a loop](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2239-2246;drc=8b80267364695624baf28f6b4ae7dfe0c1aed9c1). 2. It is used to check that the `initiating_element` is (still) [autofillable](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=1736;drc=f4a00cc248dd2dc8ec8759fb51620d47b5114090). 2. If [focused](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2257-2260;drc=f4a00cc248dd2dc8ec8759fb51620d47b5114090), the `initiating_element` gets special treatment with respect to focus: it is autofilled first, and before filling the other fields, a "blur" event is emitted, and finally a "focus" event to move the focus back into the `initiating_element`. This mechanism is needlessly convoluted because there's the second `initially_focused_element` variable. 3. The `initiating_element` has a weakened [ShouldSkipFillField()](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2251;drc=f4a00cc248dd2dc8ec8759fb51620d47b5114090) check.
Why can we eliminate it? Let's address the above use-cases: 1. Can be easily avoided: 1. The loop can just call `GetFormControlByRendererId()`. It's dead code at the moment, by the way. 2. Checking that the `initiating_field` is autofillable is reasonable -- although it covers an edge case, like elements changing from `<input type=text>` to `<input type=button>` while the popup is open -- but if we consider it useful, we should apply it also to the non-initiating fields. So should either eliminate it or move it to one the [main loop](https://source.chromium.org/chromium/chromium/src/+/main:components/autofill/content/renderer/form_autofill_util.cc;l=2258-2263;drc=8b80267364695624baf28f6b4ae7dfe0c1aed9c1). 2. Instead of using distinct `initiating_element` and `initially_focused_element`, we can set `initially_focused_element` to the autofillable that has focus, if such a field exists. The distinction between `initiating_element` and `initially_focused_element` makes a difference only in extreme race conditions because the popup is hidden when the initiating element loses focus before the user accepts a suggestion (i.e., there must be a race between the Mojo messages). In such an extreme case, if the focus has moved to another autofillable field, *that* field should get the special "blur" + "focus" treatment, IMO -- so eliminating `initiating_element` would even be a tiny bug fix. 3. We could instead check in `ShouldSkipFillField()` whether the field has focus. In the worst case, we'd be overwriting autofilled values, like in Case 2, it's only relevant in the extreme edge case, so I think it's practically irrelevant.

entry.title: Poor performance and rendering stalls with ANGLE's EGL/desktop OpenGL back end and nVidia GPUs
entry.content: I maintain VirtualGL, an interposer that enables GPU acceleration for OpenGL applications running in Un*x remote desktops (such as VNC.) Since VirtualGL does not (and probably cannot) support Vulkan, the best way to run Chrome v112+ with VirtualGL is to use ANGLE's EGL/desktop OpenGL back end (`--use-angle=gl-egl`). However, I experience frequent but intermittent rendering pipeline stalls and other performance issues with that back end, irrespective of VirtualGL (i.e. I observe them on a local display as well, simply by running `google-chrome --use-angle=gl-egl`.) The issues seem to occur only with nVidia GPUs, and I have observed them with multiple nVidia GPU models, multiple nVidia (proprietary) driver versions, and multiple Linux distributions.

entry.title: Consider updating Chrome's X11 visual selection method
entry.content:
I maintain VirtualGL, an interposer that enables GPU acceleration for OpenGL applications running in Un*x remote desktops (such as VNC.) Since VirtualGL does not (and probably cannot) support Vulkan, the best way to run Chrome v112+ with VirtualGL is to use ANGLE's EGL/desktop OpenGL back end (`--use-angle=gl-egl`). However, even though that back end doesn't use GLX, Chrome still picks an X11 visual based on GLXFBConfig attributes that it obtains by sending raw GLX protocol requests to the X server, then it expects to find an EGLConfig whose `EGL_NATIVE_VISUAL_ID` attribute matches that visual. I don't think it's necessarily valid to assume that a visual obtained using raw GLX protocol requests will automatically map to an EGLConfig, since they are different subsystems. That assumption seems to be an implementation detail, which means that Chrome's visual selection method may only work by accident.
In VirtualGL, that assumption is definitely not valid. 3D rendering actually occurs on either a "3D X server" (a GPU-attached X display that is separate from the "2D X server" specified in the DISPLAY environment variable) or an EGL device, so there is not a bidirectional mapping between GLXFBConfigs/EGLConfigs and X visuals. Applications will work fine with VirtualGL if they do one of the following:
1. Choose a GLXFBConfig with specific OpenGL rendering attributes, then call `glXGetVisualFromFBConfig()` to get its associated visual. 2. Use `glXChooseVisual()` to choose a visual with specific OpenGL rendering attributes. 3. Iterate through the available X server visuals, call `glXGetConfig()` to obtain the OpenGL rendering attributes of each, then pick one of the visuals based on those attributes. 4. Choose an EGLConfig with specific OpenGL rendering attributes, then query its `EGL_NATIVE_VISUAL_ID` attribute to get the associated visual.
Basically, Chrome implements Method 3, except that it uses raw GLX protocol requests rather than calling the actual GLX functions. By using raw GLX protocol requests, Chrome obtains a visual based on OpenGL rendering attributes from the unaccelerated (llvmpipe) OpenGL renderer in the 2D X server, and those attributes are irrelevant in VirtualGL. Because there are no function calls for VirtualGL to interpose, VGL doesn't know which visual Chrome chooses, and it can't ensure that the visual will be mapped to an EGLConfig. Is there a good reason why Chrome can't just call the GLX functions?
The comments in gfx/x/visual_manager.cc seem to indicate that Chrome is mimicking the visual selection method that GTK used to use. (GTK no longer uses that method, as of v4.3.2.) However, GTK used GLX function calls rather than raw GLX requests, so it didn't cause these problems with VirtualGL.

entry.title: ChromiumOS Media App Shim
entry.content:
I understand that the ChromeOS Media App is closed source, however, since we removed the built in video player in the Files app, the only way (and default way) to open videos and audio from the Files app is the Media app. The problem is the on ChromiumOS, it is completely empty. It is thus impossible to play media without a third party extension, or manually drag n' dropping it into a browser window.
There should be some sort of shim media app set up that can be made open source, so that the bare minimum needed to open a media file can work. Without this, ChromiumOS is hampered and difficult for developers or for making a production ready custom OS build (like I do with ThoriumOS > https://github.com/Alex313031/ThoriumOS). What I mean is none of the annotations, PDF support (I.E. use_ink), or any of that. Just a simple instance of the built in Chromium media player, enough to at least play files.
